case_name: State of Assam v. Shri B. C. Dutta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1565 of 1966 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1565 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 2, 1966 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court at Gauhati in Civil Rule No. 7 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 2, 1966 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court at Gauhati in Civil Rule No. 7 of 1966.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2, Shri B. C. Dutta was appointed the Presiding Officer of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam Gauhati by an order of the State Government dated December 7, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of the State Government dated December 7, 1965, Shri Dutta was appointed the Presiding Officer of the Indus- trial Tribunal, Assam Gauhati.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed a writ petition in the Assam High Court challenging the appointment of Shri Dutta.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 filed a writ petition in the Assam High Court challenging this appointment.

facts.text: The High Court quashed the appointment on the ground that Shri Dutta lacked the qualification required by s. 7A(3).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court quashed the appointment on the ground that Shri Dutta lacked the qualification required by s. 7A 3 .

facts.text: Shri Dutta was appointed a temporary Additional District Sessions Judge on August 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On August 16, 1954, Shri Dutta, then Officiating Subordinate and Assistant Sessions Judge, was appointed a temporary Additional District . Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Between August 16, 1954 and March 8, 1957 Shri Dutta held the office of an Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that between August 16, 1954 and March 8, 1957 Shri Dutta held the office of an Additional District Judge.

facts.text: On March 8, 1957 Shri Dutta was appointed by the Chief Justice as the Registrar of the Assam High Court.

anchor.surface_text: on March 8, 1957 was appointed by the Chief Justice as the Registrar of the Assam High Court.

facts.text: Until April 24, 1958 the Government continued to retain Shri Dutta in his office of Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The record shows that until April 24, 1958 the Government companytinued to retain Shri Dutta in his office of Additional District Judge.

facts.text: On March 26, 1958, Shri Dutta was confirmed in Senior Grade II with effect from February 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On this footing, the Government passed an order on March 26, 1958, whereby Shri Dutta, then Officiating Registrar of the High Court, was companyfirmed in Senior Grade 11 with effect from February 16, 1957.

facts.text: On April 24, 1958, Shri Dutta was confirmed in Senior Grade I with effect from May 2, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On April, 24, 1958, he was companyfirmed in Senior Grade I with effect from May 2, 1957.

facts.text: On June 30, 1959, Shri Dutta retired from the office of the Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1959, he retired from the office of the Registrar.

facts.text: Shri Dutta held the post of an Additional District Judge for over three years.

anchor.surface_text: For over three years Shri Dutta held the post of an Additional District Judge.

facts.text: During the period from March 8, 1957 up to April 24, 1958, Shri Dutta continued to hold the office of an Additional District Judge while officiating as Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that during the period from March 8, 1957 up to April 24, 1958, Shri Dutta, while officiating as a Registrar of the High Court, companytinued to hold the office of an Additional District Judge.

facts.text: The appointment of Shri Dutta was made without consultation with the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment of Shri Dutta as the Presiding Officer of the Industrial Tribunal was made without companysultation with the High Court.

facts.text: Section 7A was inserted in the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 by Act No. 36 of 1956 with effect from March 10, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7A inserted in the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 by Act No. 36 of 1956 with effect from March 10, 1957 read as follows - 7A  1  The appropriate Government may,

facts.text: Assam Act No. 8 of 1952 received the assent of the President on April 25, 1962 and inserted clause aa in s. 7A(3).

anchor.surface_text: Assam Act No. 8 of 1952 which received the assent of the President on April 25, 1962 inserted in s. 7A 3  after cl.  a , the following clause -  aa  he has worked as a District judge

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Amendment Act No. 36 of 1964 inserted clause aa in s. 7A(3).

anchor.surface_text: In 1964, the Parliament passed the Industrial Disputes  Amendment  Act  No. 36 of 1964 . This amending Act inserted in s. 7A 3 after cl.  a  the following clause  aa  he has, for a period

facts.text: Before December 7, 1965, Shri Dutta had been the Presiding Officer of a Labour Court for over two years.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before December 7, 1965, Shri Dutta had been the Presiding Officer of a Labour Court for over two years.

facts.text: The High Court held that Shri Dutta never held the office of the District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in saying that under the Assam Judicial Service  Senior  Rules, 1952 the post of the Registrar was separate from that of the District Judge and Shri Dutta never held the office of the District Judge.

facts.text: Counsel for the State of Assam submitted that Shri Dutta had been an Additional District Judge for over three years.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State of Assam submitted that Shri Dutta had been an Additional District Judge for over three years, and was,, therefore, qualified for appointment.

facts.text: The appeal is allowed with costs against respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed with companyts against, respondent No.

facts.text: Shri Dutta was qualified for appointment under s. 7A(3)(aa) inserted by Central Act No. 36 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that Shri Dutta was duly qualified for appoint- ment under s. 7A 3  aa , and the order of the High Court must be set aside.

facts.text: Clause aa inserted by Assam Act was impliedly repealed by Central Act No. 36 of 1964 to the extent of repugnancy.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the subject-matter of the appointment of a person who has for a period of number less than three years been a District Judge or an Additional District Judge, cl.  aa  inserted by Central Act No. 36 of 1964 impliedly repealed cl.  aa  inserted by the Assam Act.

facts.text: Shri Dutta was not qualified under s.7A(3)(b) because Labour Court is not a Tribunal within s.2(r).

anchor.surface_text: But a Labour Court is number a Tribunal within the meaning of s. 7A 3   b  read with s. 2 r . Shri Dutta was, therefore, number qualified for appointment under s.7A 3  b .

issues.text: whether respondent No. 2, Shri B. C. Dutta was qualified for appointment as the Presiding Officer of an Industrial Tribunal under s. 7A 3  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question whether respondent No. 2, Shri B. C. Dutta was qualified for appointment as the Presiding Officer of an Industrial Tribunal under s. 7A 3  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

issues.text: whether Shri Dutta, while working as Registrar of the Assam High Court, held the office of an Additional District Judge

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State of Assam submitted that Shri Dutta had been an Additional District Judge for over three years, and was,, therefore, qualified for appointment. This submission involves companysideration of the question whether Shri Dutta, while working as Registrar of the Assam High Court, held the office of an Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was in error in thinking that in order to satisfy the companyditions of s. 7A 3  aa , Shri Dutta should have actually worked as an Additional District Judge for a period of number less than three years.

arguments.claim: Assam cl.aa repugnant to Central cl.aa and void to extent of repugnancy under Art.254; Central Act occupies the field

anchor.surface_text: The Central Act now occupies this field. The provisions of cl. aa inserted by the Assam Act on this subject are repugnant to cl. aa inserted by the Central Act and by Art. 254 of the Constitution, to the extent of this repugnancy, is void.

arguments.claim: Shri Dutta continued to hold office of Additional District Judge from March 8, 1957 to April 24, 1958 while officiating as Registrar

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that during the period from March 8, 1957 up to April 24, 1958, Shri Dutta, while officiating as a Registrar of the High Court, continued to hold the office of an Additional District Judge.

holdings.text: Shri Dutta continued to hold the office of an Additional District Judge during the period from March 8, 1957 up to April 24, 1958 while officiating as a Registrar of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that during the period from March 8, 1957 up to April 24, 1958, Shri Dutta, while officiating as a Registrar of the High Court, continued to hold the office of an Additional District Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government records show continued retention in the office and confirmation in senior grades while officiating as Registrar.

holdings.text: For over three years Shri Dutta held the post of an Additional District Judge and consequently had been an Additional District Judge as required by s. 7A(3)(aa).

anchor.surface_text: For over three years Shri Dutta held the post of an Additional District Judge. Consequently, during this period he had been an Additional District Judge as required by s. 7A 3  aa . To satisfy the requirements of s. 7A 3  aa  it was

holdings.reasoning_summary: Continuous holding of office from 1954 to 1958 satisfies the period requirement under the provision.

holdings.text: To satisfy the requirements of s. 7A(3)(aa) it was not necessary that Shri Dutta must have actually worked as an Additional District Judge for a period of not less than three years.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was in error in thinking that in order to satisfy the conditions of s. 7A 3  aa , Shri Dutta should have actually worked as an Additional District Judge for a period of not less than three years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The phrase 'been a District Judge or Additional District Judge' means held the office, not necessarily discharged judicial duties.

holdings.text: In respect of the subject-matter of the appointment of a person who has for a period of not less than three years been a District Judge or an Additional District Judge, cl. aa inserted by Central Act No. 36 of 1964 impliedly repealed cl. aa inserted by the Assam Act.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the subject-matter of the appointment of a person who has for a period of not less than three years been a District Judge or an Additional District Judge, cl. aa  inserted by Central Act No. 36 of 1964 impliedly repealed cl.  aa  inserted by the Assam Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Central clause intended as exhaustive code on the subject-matter.

holdings.text: The provisions of cl. aa inserted by the Assam Act on this subject are repugnant to cl. aa inserted by the Central Act and by Art. 254 of the Constitution, to the extent of this repugnancy, is void.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Act now occupies this field. The provisions of cl. aa  inserted by the Assam Act on this subject are repugnant to cl. aa  inserted by the Central Act and by Art. 254 of the Constitution, to the extent of this repugnancy, is void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Central Act occupies the field making state provision repugnant under constitutional repugnancy doctrine.

holdings.text: Clause aa of s. 7A(3) inserted by the Central Act does not require any consultation with the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  aa  of s. 7A 3  inserted by the Central Act does not require any consultation with the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevailing central provision lacks proviso requiring consultation present in state version.

holdings.text: Shri Dutta was duly qualified for appointment under s. 7A(3)(aa).

anchor.surface_text: It follows that Shri Dutta was duly qualified for appoint- ment under s. 7A 3  aa , and the order of the High Court must be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfied holding office requirement under prevailing central clause (aa).

holdings.text: A Labour Court is not a Tribunal within the meaning of s. 7A(3)(b) read with s. 2(r); Shri Dutta was therefore not qualified under s.7A(3)(b).

anchor.surface_text: But a Labour Court is not a Tribunal within the meaning of s. 7A 3   b  read with s. 2 r . Shri Dutta was, therefore, not qualified for appointment under s.7A 3  b .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition of Tribunal in s.2(r) refers to Industrial Tribunals under s.7A or pre-1957 s.7, excluding Labour Courts.

holdings.text: In respect of the subject of appointment of a person who is qualified for appointment as a Judge of a High Court, clause aa inserted by Assam Act No. 8 of 1962 including its proviso continues to be in force.

anchor.surface_text: We may add that in respect of the subject of appointment of a person who is qualified for appointment as a Judge of a High Court, clause  aa  inserted by Assam Act No. 8 of 1962 including its proviso continues to be in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing scope of repeal to unrelated part of state clause.
